questions.question: What keyword should be avoided for variable declaration due to its lack of block scope?
Which variable declaration should be used when the variable needs to be reassigned within its scope?
Functions can be declared using the function keyword followed by a name and parameters.
What keyword is used to return values from a function?
What does function hoisting mean in JavaScript?
choices: Functions are pushed to the bottom of their scope.
Functions are lifted to the top of their scope.
Functions are removed from their scope.

questions.question: Which ScriptType is used for executing custom NetSuite pages using server-side JavaScript?
What is an example of an EntryPoint for UserEventScript?
Which API is used to create, read, update, and delete records in NetSuite?
What should be done before deploying a script to production in NetSuite?
choices: Skip following NetSuite's deployment best practices.
Deploy directly to production without a sandbox.
Associate the script with the appropriate record type.

questions.question: What should be ensured before deploying a script to production in NetSuite?
choices: Avoid following NetSuite's deployment best practices.
Properly test the script in a sandbox account.
Ignore any disruptions to the system during deployment.
Deploy without associating with any record type.

questions.question: Which ScriptType is commonly used for form validation and user interface enhancements on the client side?
What does block scope refer to in JavaScript?
choices: The scope of a variable defined within a function.
The scope of a variable declared with the const keyword.
The scope of a variable declared with the let keyword.
The scope of a variable limited to the block ({}) in which it is defined.

questions.question: What is an example of an EntryPoint for Suitelet?
Which API is used to execute ad hoc queries against the NetSuite database??
What is the purpose of the runtime API in SuiteScript 2.1?
choices: To create, read, update, and delete records.
To provide information about the current script execution context.
To schedule scripts to run at specified intervals.

questions.question: What is the syntax for invoking a function named myFunction with no parameters?
What happens if a function in JavaScript does not explicitly return a value?
Variables declared with var are function-scoped or globally scoped. They can be hoisted, reassigned and redeclared within their scope. What is true about var x = 10?
choices: var x = 10 will stay where it was declared in its scope
var = 10 is automatically globally scoped no matter where it is in the script

questions.question: Variables declared with let are block-scoped. They can be reassigned but not redeclared within their scope. They are not hoisted, so you cannot access them before the line they're declared on. What is true about let x = 10
choices: let x = 30; // SyntaxError: Identifier 'x' has already been declared
let x = 10 // can be declared again within the same block scope

questions.question: We use const when you want to declare a variable that won't be reassigned. What is true about variables declared using const?
choices: Variables declared with const are not block-scoped.
They can be reassigned or redeclared within their scope.
const variables must be initialized at the time of declaration and cannot be left uninitialized.

questions.question: Block scope refers to the scope of a variable within the block of code where it is defined. In JavaScript, a block is typically defined by a pair of curly braces {}. Examples of blocks include:
choices: blocks created by if, else, switch

questions.question: Passing Parameters: Parameters are variables listed as part of the function definition. They act as placeholders for values that will be provided when the function is invoked. Which part of this function is the parameter to be passed?
choices: The word FUNCTION in function greet(name)
The name Alice when the function greet(name) is executed
The word GREET in the function greet(name)
The word NAME in function greet(name)

questions.question: Method: In JavaScript, a method is a function that is a property of an object. It allows objects to perform actions or computations. Methods are invoked using dot notation. What does this look like?
To invoke a method on an object, one must:
choices: use dot notation with the object's name followed by the method name and curly braces like so: objectName.methodName{}
use dash notation with the object's name followed by the method name and parentheses like so: objectName-methodName()
use dot notation with the object's name followed by the method number and parentheses like so: objectName.4()
use dot notation with the object's name followed by the method name and parentheses like so: objectName.methodName()

questions.question: How should scripts be deployed to NetSuite to avoid disruptions to the system?
choices: Without testing in a sandbox account.
By associating them with random record types.
Following NetSuite's deployment best practices and guidelines.
Deploying directly to production without any preparation.

questions.question: Which ScriptType is used to define a search that can be reused and scheduled?
What is the purpose of the log API in SuiteScript 2.1?
choices: To retrieve data from NetSuite using saved searches.
To execute ad hoc queries against the NetSuite database.
To create, read, update, and delete records in NetSuite.
To log messages to the NetSuite execution log.

questions.question: Which keyword is used to declare a function in JavaScript?
Which EntryPoint is triggered before submitting a record in UserEventScript?
Which API is used to schedule scripts to run at specified intervals?
When declaring a variable with const, can its value be reassigned?
choices: Only within the same block scope

questions.question: What is the purpose of block-scoping variables with let?
choices: To declare variables with global scope.
To declare variables with function scope.
To declare variables with block scope.

questions.question: Suitelets allow custom NetSuite pages to be created using server-side JavaScript.
